title: 106_hr4744
content: The Act may be cited as the "Truth in Regulating Act of 2000". The "Truth in Regulating Act of 2000" aims to increase transparency in regulatory decisions and promote effective congressional oversight to ensure proper implementation of laws by the executive branch. Congress recognizes the need for accurate information to make informed decisions and address uncontrolled regulatory costs. The "Truth in Regulating Act of 2000" aims to increase transparency in regulatory decisions, promote effective congressional oversight, and enhance accountability of Congress and agencies to the people they serve. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "agency" is defined as in section 551(1) of title 5, United States Code. An "economically significant rule" refers to a proposed or final rule with a significant economic impact or affecting various aspects. An "independent evaluation" involves assessing data, methodology, and assumptions related to economically significant rules. An "independent evaluation" involves a substantive assessment of an agency's and the public's data, methodology, and assumptions used in developing economically significant rules. This evaluation includes explaining how strengths or weaknesses in the data, methodology, and assumptions impact the agency's conclusions and the implications for the rulemaking process. SEC. 4. REPORT ON RULES. When an agency publishes an economically significant rule, a committee member can request the Comptroller General to review it. The Comptroller General must submit a report on the rule to the relevant committees in Congress within specific timeframes. The Comptroller General must submit an independent evaluation of the economically significant rule to Congress within specific timeframes, including an assessment of potential benefits and beneficiaries. The Comptroller General must provide an evaluation of the potential benefits and costs of a rule, including any unquantifiable effects, alternative approaches, and reasons for not adopting them. The evaluation of alternative approaches for cost-effectiveness, regulatory impact analysis, and changes made in the final rule by the agency are important considerations. The Comptroller General evaluates agency rule changes and prioritizes requests for review based on proposed and interim rules. The Comptroller General evaluates agency rule changes, giving priority to requests regarding proposed and interim rules. Each agency must cooperate promptly with the Comptroller General in carrying out the Act. Authorization of appropriations for the General Accounting Office is set at $5,200,000 for fiscal years 2001 through 2003. The Act will take effect 180 days after enactment and will not apply to rules published 3 years after the effective date.
